blog.description: President Obama will soon be sworn into office, and whether you voted for him or not, he's everybody's president. What do you want him to remember in his second term? We will feature your responses in our inauguration coverage!
blog.title: Dear Mr. President
blog.name: inauguration2013

posts.caption:
Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

As I grow older I become more unwilling to put my faith in the powers that be. I feel that because I’m not a ‘corporate person’ or wealthy individual, my voice really has no sway. My government doesn’t feel like it cares about me or my concerns. This is dispiriting.

Signed,
Tiffany M. Conner from Austin, Texas

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

One day when I was little I arrived home from school ahead of my sisters. There was a man, a black man, sitting on our porch. We lived in the south and this was the early 60’s. My mother came out the door and said to me “He was hungry so I fed him. Don’t tell you father.” This Christmas our daughter came to us with a concern for one of her classmates, his name is Jamail. Jamail, along with his mother and sister, were living in a very cheap motel and where being kicked out with no place to go. My heart broke. I had studied poverty in college but studing it is not the same as experiencing it and with Jamail and his family I was getting a close of picture it. We dropped food off at the motel for them nearly every night during the holidays. It seems as if I cried every time on the drive back home. We simply have too many living in poverty in this wealthy country of ours, it is morally wrong. We need to work together to lift people out with better schools, living wages, affordable housing, and affordable, decent child care. We need to also change the perception that poor people are lazy wanting only governmental handouts. Jamail and his family have become a part of our family and I am working with Jamail’s mom to find additional resources so that they could move out of the motel.

Signed,
Sharon Jacobs from Houston, TX

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

This is my son. His life, and what he eats matters to me. Please stop the use of GMO plants, fish, and other products. We do not know enough about the longtime effects. Please push for more investigation into these products.

Signed,
Lindsay Chard from North Charleston, SC

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

I want you to remember that there will be no economy without either education or the environment. I don’t believe America has an education system worthy of such a great nation. The youth are more immersed in technology and social networking than in education and without an intelligent population we will wither and disintegrate. I also believe that if we don’t pay more attention to the environment then we will be doomed to live in a word that we really can’t live in and still lead a healthy life. Combining these two topics seems incredibly important so the population of America is aware of the problems that are around them and will be knowledgeable enough to work to fix the problems.

Signed,
James DeSoto from Paradise, CA

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Climate change is wreaking havoc on our world, including our pollinators.

I am a biodynamic beekeeper and I would like you to know that these last few years have been very difficult for bees because of the ongoing and extreme drought. The bees don’t have enough nectar to sustain themselves if there is drought. Recent winters have also been warmer than normal and this means that the bees actually need more honey to make it through the winter - honey which they don’t have because of the previous summer’s drought.

If we lose the honeybees and the other pollinators, we lose most of our agriculture. Do you want to eat only wind-pollinated corn, wheat and oat mush for breakfast, lunch and dinner? Neither do I.

We must bring the atmospheric carbon dioxide levels down to 350 ppm or we will lose the pollinators. We must mitigate this Climate Crisis to a level where life is still imaginable and the Earth is still inhabitable - 350 ppm.

Signed,
Judith Moran from Highlands Ranch, CO

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Dear Mr. President,

Mining dirty tar sands oil in Alberta is destroying pristine Canadian boreal forest and the health and lifestyle of thousands of native Canadian people. Burning it will also contribute to climate change. According to NASA’s Dr. James Hansen, if all the oil from the tar sands is burned, it’s ‘game over’ for the climate. Do not approve the Keystone XL pipeline!!!!!!!!!!!

We need clean renewable energy: wind, solar, algae, tidal. We don’t need fictitious “clean coal” or more air-and-water-polluting fracked gas. There are clean alternatives that need federal support so they can compete with fossil fuels.

For your children, for my children, and for all future generations…..please make climate change your top priority! There is not a moment to waste.

Thank you.

Signed,
Nancy from Lexington MA

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Both of my boys have autism. It seems like everyone I know has a child on the spectrum. Our community is growing but we don’t know why and, as a result, we aren’t providing the best services and supports for people with autism. I especially worry about adults, who get next to nothing. We need research on the causes and best interventions for autism. We need a federal mandate to make sure all insurance companies cover autism services.

Signed,
Ellen Cicconi from Canonsburg PA

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

Both of my boys have autism. It seems like everyone I know has a child on the spectrum. Our community is growing but we don’t know why and, as a result, we aren’t providing the best services and supports for people with autism. I especially worry about adults, who get next to nothing. We need research on the causes and best interventions for autism. We need a federal mandate to make sure all insurance companies cover autism services.

Signed,
Ellen Cicconi from Canonsburg PA

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Both are sad.
Neither can be completly stopped, but we can stop paying for one of them with our tax dollars

Signed,
marvin from germantown tn

Dear Mr. President,

I’d rather not say how I voted.

I do, however, support you.

Act with fearless integrity. In 2008, you offered us hope, a break from the political status quo – Change. First terms are largely influenced by polls and popularity. After all, you have to win that second, right? President Obama, sir, you have been re-elected because, despite the to-ing and fro-ing of the first term, there are people, like me, who believe in you.

You are an intelligent man. You know what’s important. We MUST fix the economy. YOU MUST set us on that path. We MUST remove Washington from the hands of the lobbyists and special interest groups and return it to the hands of the people. We MUST remove the demagogues from our houses of government and replace them with men and women of integrity and true love and concern for the people – ALL the people – of this country. We MUST be the leader of the free world that we claim to be – and lead fearlessly from the front, earning the respect and trust of our fellow nations through the indivisibility of our policies and our actions.

These are major MUSTS, and they are only a few, but we have the tools to make a start. We have a military that can rebuild the infrastructure of a foreign nation – how about we turn them loose on rebuilding some cities here at home? We both owe and lend billions upon billions of dollars to other nations – how about we don’t loan money we don’t have and stop printing money we can’t back up? We have an incredible University education system, which fewer students can afford to attend every year, but our elementary and high school systems are abysmal. We have a functioning House and Senate, though apparently without the occupants with the intestinal fortitude to get much of any real value done. We have a government with great resources and a nation of endless variety and possibility, of which you are the head. Yet we cannot find our path. Where have our priorities gone?

You cannot address these all in four years – maybe not even in forty – but you can address some. Select your issues and act. Act fearlessly, Mr. President. Act with integrity and without apology, with sober deliberation, trustworthy and honorable advisors and a humble heart. But Act. When in doubt, look to your people, not to the pundits – we are much less jaded and cynical. This is the world that our children – that YOUR children – will inherit. I encourage you, President Obama, with all the determination of a mother’s soul, to do your utmost as the leader of the most powerful nation on earth, to make changes that you will be proud to pass on to the future.

Fearless. Integrity. Sir.

Your very faithful and true supporter and friend,

Signed,
Megan Leigh Gutierrez from Fort Bragg, NC
